book.title: Power API Authentication Component Deployment Handbook

abstract.para: This document is intended for systems administrators interested in configuring their service to use the Client Authenticaion component of the Rackspace Cloud Power Application Program Interface (API).

section.title: Purpose
section.para: The purpose of this handbook is to facilitate deployment of Power API's client authentication component. This handbook is not a tutorial. It provides basic information that will help you understand and deploy this Power API component, but you must adapt this information to suit your own configuration.

The client authentication service filter enables the origin service to communicate with the authentication service implemented in its environment. It accomplishes this by delegating authentication requests to the authentication service and returning the results of those requests to the origin service.
This handbook is focused on one Power API component. Other Power API components are documented in companion handbooks.

chapter.title: Configuration
chapter.para: Client Authentication is divided into interchangable modules which represent different authentication schemes. Depending on the Power API components being deployed, the authentication configuration may change. In the example below, we are configuring the client-auth component to interact with Rackspace Cloud Authentication v1.1.

callout.para: In accordance with http://wiki.openstack.org/openstack-authn all authentications modules support authentication delegation. Delegation may be enabled or disabled by setting the rackspace-auth attribute "delegatable" to true or false. To better protect services, delegation always defaults to false.

The authentication-server element is used to tell the component which authentication end-point to validate tokens against. While the password is required in this configuration file, it is important to note that file permissions can be set to make this file user-readable only and therefore marginally safer.

The URI attribute of the authentication-server configuration element informs the component of where it must route token validation requests. This URI must include all necessary information required to make an HTTP request, including the port number the service is listening on as well as the authentication service's context root.
The authentication service's context root is /auth in this case.

Account mappings in the configuration inform the component of where in client requested URIs to source the client's identity string from. This is achieved via a regular expression (regex). In this regular expression the service implementor is required to specify a regular expression capture group which, when executed, will capture the requesting client's identity string. This string will then be sent to the authentication service. The type of account must be specified in the type attribute.

section.title: Setting Active Limits
section.para: The API endpoint is specified in rate-limiting.xml.

listitem.para: The limits-request-endpoint configuration element must specify a regex that identifies client requests for the client's currently active limits.
The uri-regex attribute should be a regular expression that matches all request resource representations that the rate limiting component should answer.
Optionally, include-absolute-limits is a Boolean attribute that can be used to switch on or off absolute limits integration.

row.entry: The uri attribute of a given limit should be a human-readable representation of the regular expression used to match this limit. The URI is useful for client end-user interfaces as well as for documentation purposes.
The uri-regex attribute should be a regular expression that matches all request resource representations to which the given limit should apply.

Limits can trigger on specific HTTP methods. These trigger methods must be specified by the http-methods attribute. As the name implies, the attribute may contain more than one value; multiple values are delimited by spaces. The rate limiting component supports all valid HTTP methods as described by RFC 2616 at http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2616.txt. If the configuration specifies ALL for the http-methods attribute, this informs the rate limiting component that rate limiting should occur on all HTTP requests.
GET, DELETE, POST, PUT, HEAD, TRACE, OPTIONS, CONNECT, ALL

Every limit must specify a time unit specified by the unit attribute. The valid values for this attribute are also enumerated in the OpenStack limits XML schema XSD file at http://docs.openstack.org/common/api/v1.0.

A limit's value attribute is an integer which describes the number of requests the limit allows. In combination with the unit attribute, the number of requests within a slice of time describes the rate for the given limit. The rate is then used to perform rate limiting.

section.title: Configuring Limit Groups
section.para: Limit groups identify a group of related rate limits and bind them to a series of names. The names can be used to limit incoming requests using the X-PP-Groups header.

A single limit group may be defined as the default. This default will handle any requests that cannot be matched on the basis of a group name to any of the groups identified in the X-PP-Groups header.

section.title: Constructing Cache Keys
section.para: The rate limiting component must be able to track active rate limits per resource. To effectively facilitate this, the rate limiting component attempts to generate a cache key from the limit's regular expression, as defined in its uri-regex attribute. Extracting cache keys from the regular expression is performed via regular expression capture groups.

If no capture groups are specified, then the entire request URI is used as a the cache key for the request. This is considered sub-optimal in most cases, since each unique resource representation will have requests made against it tracked separately.

important.para: Keep in mind that query parameters as well as other request URI components ARE included as part of the request URI that the rate limiting component operates against and should be considered when constructing your regular expressions.

section.para: Consider the following regular expression: /service/.*

This is a blanket regular expression that will catch any request against a resource that falls under the parent resource, service. Because the rate limiting component cannot detect whether the service implementer is requesting that each resource request be tracked separately or as part of a group, the component defaults to tracking limited requests under unique keys.
Consider the following regular expression: /service/([^!*'();:@=+$,/?#\\[\\]]*)/.*
This regular expression generates cache keys from the second-tier resource in a given request URI. This is useful for grouping child resources under a shared rate limit.

note.para: Service implementers should use capture groups in their regular expressions. In addition, the performance of the regular expression should be taken into consideration when designing limits. This is because a given expression's performance has a direct impact on the rate limiting component's performance and throughput.

chapter.title: Recording Client Requests
chapter.para: The rate limiting component must be able to both record request usage on a per-limit basis and recall all stored limits that belong to a named client. The X-PP-User is used for this purpose.

section.title: Cache Indexing
section.para: The caching format for the rate limiting component is designed for high throughput. Because of this, an aggregation index is required to group active rate limits to a named client.

The rate limiting component indexes stored limit cache keys in a separate cached object for each named client identified the X-PP-User HTTP header. This data structure is called the user limit key lookaside. This index is needed to maintain O(1) logic to use a cache key to get cached limits. Without this index, acquiring a cached limit would require either more complex &GET; logic or caching logic that is not easily scalable.
The string value of the X-PP-User HTTP header is treated as the cache key for this index.

note.para: This index is not updated for every cache &PUT;. The index is updated when a new cache object for a limit is inserted. When an existing cache object is updated, the index is not updated.

section.title: Single-Node Installation
section.para: The rate limiting component supports a single-node Power API installation in which all cache operations are performed locally. Power API's default local datastore is used when no other nodes are identified in the system model as hosting a rate limiting component.

section.title: Multi-Node Installation
section.para: The rate limiting component supports multiple-node Power API installations via Power API's datastore service. If a clustered datastore is available, the component will make use of it. The rate limiting component only currently supports discovery of Power API's default hash-ring clustered datastore.

chapter.title: Requesting Active Limits
chapter.para: A client may request from the rate limiting component their currently active rate and or absolute limits.

Valid accept types are:
application/xml
application/json

entry.programlisting: GET /service/limits HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/vnd.rackspace-v1.0+xml X-PP-User: username X-PP-Groups: customer

chapter.title: Integrating Absolute Limits
chapter.para: The rate limiting component is designed to integrate with limits that are returned as a response from the origin service. These limits are absolute and are specific to a service domain.
To activate inclusion of absolute limits that are specific to a client's origin service, the optional configuration attribute, `include-absolute-limits`, may be used.

When `include-absolute-limits` is set to true, the rate limiting component marks incoming requests that match the the limit request endpoint's `uri-regex` and then passes them down to the origin service. After the origin service responds with the client's absolute limits, the rate limiting component enhances the response with the combined absolute and active rate limits. It then sends the response to the client.

chapter.title: Handling Limited Client Requests
chapter.para: When a client makes a request that exceeds the client's specified rate limit, the rate limiting component will return the HTTP response code 413 (Request Entity Too Large).

entry.programlisting: GET /service/my/resource HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/vnd.rackspace-v1.0+xml X-PP-User: username X-PP-Groups: customer
HTTP/1.1 413 Request Entity Too Large Retry-After: Thu, 30 Jun 2011 20:24:39 GMT
